12. (1) A Data Principal shall have the right to correction, completion, updating and
erasure of her personal data for the processing of which she has previously given consent,
including consent as referred to in clause (a) of section 7, in accordance with any requirement
or procedure under any law for the time being in force.
(2) A Data Fiduciary shall, upon receiving a request for correction, completion or
updating from a Data Principal,—
(a) correct the inaccurate or misleading personal data;
(b) complete the incomplete personal data; and
(c) update the personal data.
(3) A Data Principal shall make a request in such manner as may be prescribed to the
Data Fiduciary for erasure of her personal data, and upon receipt of such a request, the Data
Fiduciary shall erase her personal data unless retention of the same is necessary for the
specified purpose or for compliance with any law for the time being in force.
13. (1) A Data Principal shall have the right to have readily available means of grievance
redressal provided by a Data Fiduciary or Consent Manager in respect of any act or omission
of such Data Fiduciary or Consent Manager regarding the performance of its obligations in
relation to the personal data of such Data Principal or the exercise of her rights under the
provisions of this Act and the rules made thereunder.
(2) The Data Fiduciary or Consent Manager shall respond to any grievances referred
to in sub-section (1) within such period as may be prescribed from the date of its receipt for
all or any class of Data Fiduciaries.
(3) The Data Principal shall exhaust the opportunity of redressing her grievance
under this section before approaching the Board.
14. (1) A Data Principal shall have the right to nominate, in such manner as may be
prescribed, any other individual, who shall, in the event of death or incapacity of the Data
Principal, exercise the rights of the Data Principal in accordance with the provisions of this
Act and the rules made thereunder.
(2) For the purposes of this section, the expression “incapacity” means inability to
exercise the rights of the Data Principal under the provisions of this Act or the rules made
thereunder due to unsoundness of mind or infirmity of  body.
15.  A Data Principal shall perform the following duties, namely:—
(a) comply with the provisions of all applicable laws for the time being in force
while exercising rights under the provisions of this Act;
(b) to ensure not to impersonate another person while providing her personal
data for a specified purpose;
(c) to ensure not to suppress any material information while providing her
personal data for any document, unique identifier, proof of identity or proof of address
issued by the State or any of its instrumentalities;
(d) to ensure not to register a false or frivolous grievance or complaint with a
Data Fiduciary or the Board; and
(e) to furnish only such information as is verifiably authentic, while exercising
the right to correction or erasure under the provisions of this Act or the rules made
thereunder.

controls.control_title: Implement Personal Data Erasure Request Processing

controls.control: Regularly review and update personal data erasure processes to ensure they remain effective and compliant with changing regulations and standards.

extracted_data.requirement_title: Restriction on Transfer of Personal Data
extracted_data.article_text:
SEC. 1] THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY 11
CHAPTER IV
SPECIAL PROVISIONS
16. (1) The Central Government may, by notification, restrict the transfer of personal
data by a Data Fiduciary for processing to such country or territory outside India as may be
so notified.
(2) Nothing contained in this section shall restrict the applicability of any law for the
time being in force in India that provides for a higher degree of protection for or restriction
on transfer of personal data by a Data Fiduciary outside India in relation to any personal
data or Data Fiduciary or class thereof.
17. (1) The provisions of Chapter II, except sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 8, and
those of Chapter III and section 16 shall not apply where—
(a) the processing of personal data is necessary for enforcing any legal right or
claim;
(b) the processing of personal data by any court or tribunal or any other body
in India which is entrusted by law with the performance of any judicial or quasi-judicial
or regulatory or supervisory function, where such processing is necessary for the
performance of such function;
(c) personal data is processed in the interest of prevention, detection,
investigation or prosecution of any offence or contravention of any law for the time
being in force in India;
(d) personal data of Data Principals not within the territory of India is processed
pursuant to any contract entered into with any person outside the territory of India
by any person based in India;
(e) the processing is necessary for a scheme of compromise or arrangement or
merger or amalgamation of two or more companies or a reconstruction by way of
demerger or otherwise of a company, or transfer of undertaking of one or more company
to another company, or involving division of one or more companies, approved by a
court or tribunal or other authority competent to do so by any law for the time being
in force; and
(f) the processing is for the purpose of ascertaining the financial information
and assets and liabilities of any person who has defaulted in payment due on account
of a loan or advance taken from a financial institution, subject to such processing
being in accordance with the provisions regarding disclosure of information or data
in any other law for the time being in force.
Explanation.— For the purposes of this clause, the expressions “default” and
“financial institution” shall have the meanings respectively assigned to them in
sub-sections (12) and (14) of section 3 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016.
Illustration.
X, an individual, takes a loan from Y , a bank.  X defaults in paying her monthly loan
repayment instalment on the date on which it falls due. Y may process the personal data of
X for ascertaining her financial information and assets and liabilities.
(2) The provisions of this Act shall not apply in respect of the processing of personal
data—
(a) by such instrumentality of the State as the Central Government may notify,
in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly
relations with foreign States, maintenance of public order or preventing incitement to
any cognizable offence relating to any of these, and the processing by the Central
Government of any personal data that such instrumentality may furnish to it; and

controls.control_title: Conduct a Risk Assessment for International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall conduct a thorough risk assessment to identify potential risks associated with transferring personal data to countries or territories outside India. This assessment shall consider factors such as the recipient country's data protection laws, the type of data being transferred, and the potential impact on individuals.

controls.control_title: Obtain Prior Approval for International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall obtain prior approval from the Central Government before transferring personal data to countries or territories outside India. This approval shall be obtained through a formal application process, which may include providing documentation and justifying the need for the transfer.

The Data Fiduciary shall implement data transfer agreements with recipients in countries or territories outside India. These agreements shall include provisions for data protection, confidentiality, and security, as well as mechanisms for resolving disputes and complaints.

controls.control_title: Maintain Records of International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall maintain accurate and up-to-date records of all international data transfers, including the type of data transferred, the recipient country or territory, and the date of transfer. These records shall be retained for a minimum of 5 years and made available to the Central Government upon request.

controls.control_title: Ensure Compliance with Notified Countries or Territories
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall ensure that all international data transfers comply with the data protection laws and regulations of the notified countries or territories. This shall include obtaining necessary certifications, registrations, or approvals, and implementing measures to ensure compliance with local data protection requirements.

extracted_data.article_text:
CHAPTER V
D
ATA PROTECTION BOARD OF INDIA
18. (1) With effect from such date as the Central Government may, by notification,
appoint, there shall be established, for the purposes of this Act, a Board to be called the
Data Protection Board of India.
(2) The Board shall be a body corporate by the name aforesaid, having perpetual
succession and a common seal, with power, subject to the provisions of this Act, to acquire,
hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and to contract and shall, by
the said name, sue or be sued.
(3) The headquarters of the Board shall be at such place as the Central Government
may notify.
19. (1) The Board shall consist of a Chairperson and such number of other Members
as the Central Government may notify.
(2) The Chairperson and other Members shall be appointed by the Central Government
in such manner as may be prescribed.
(3) The Chairperson and other Members shall be a person of ability, integrity and
standing who possesses special knowledge or practical experience in the fields of data
governance, administration or implementation of laws related to social or consumer
protection, dispute resolution, information and communication technology, digital economy,
law, regulation or techno-regulation, or in any other field which in the opinion of the Central
Government may be useful to the Board, and at least one among them shall be an expert in
the field of law.
20. ( 1) The salary, allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the
Chairperson and other Members shall be such as may be prescribed, and shall not be varied
to their disadvantage after their appointment.
(2) The Chairperson and other Members shall hold office for a term of two years and
shall be eligible for re-appointment.

extracted_data.requirement_title: Disqualification for Chairperson or Member Appointment
extracted_data.article_text:
SEC. 1] THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY 13
21. (1) A person shall be disqualified for being appointed and continued as the
Chairperson or a Member, if she—
(a) has been adjudged as an insolvent;
(b) has been convicted of an offence, which in the opinion of the Central
Government, involves moral turpitude;
(c) has become physically or mentally incapable of acting as a Member;
(d) has acquired such financial or other interest, as is likely to affect prejudicially
her functions as a Member; or
(e) has so abused her position as to render her continuance in office prejudicial
to the public interest.
(2) The Chairperson or Member shall not be removed from her office by the Central
Government unless she has been given an opportunity of being heard in the matter.
22. (1) The Chairperson or any other Member may give notice in writing to the Central
Government of resigning from her office, and such resignation shall be effective from the
date on which the Central Government permits her to relinquish office, or upon expiry of a
period of three months from the date of receipt of such notice, or upon a duly appointed
successor entering upon her office, or upon the expiry of the term of her office, whichever
is earliest.
(2) A vacancy caused by the resignation or removal or death of the Chairperson or
any other Member, or otherwise, shall be filled by fresh appointment in accordance with the
provisions of this Act.
(3) The Chairperson and any other Member shall not, for a period of one year from the
date on which they cease to hold such office, except with the previous approval of the
Central Government, accept any employment, and shall also disclose to the Central
Government any subsequent acceptance of employment with any Data Fiduciary against
whom proceedings were initiated by or before such Chairperson or other Member.
23. ( 1) The Board shall observe such procedure in regard to the holding of and
transaction of business at its meetings, including by digital means, and authenticate its
orders, directions and instruments in such manner as may be prescribed.
(2) No act or proceeding of the Board shall be invalid merely by reason of—
(a) any vacancy in or any defect in the constitution of the Board;
(b) any defect in the appointment of a person acting as the Chairperson or other
Member of the Board; or
(c) any irregularity in the procedure of the Board, which does not affect the
merits of the case.
(3) When the Chairperson is unable to discharge her functions owing to absence,
illness or any other cause, the senior-most Member shall discharge the functions of the
Chairperson until the date on which the Chairperson resumes her duties.
24. The Board may, with previous approval of the Central Government, appoint such
officers and employees as it may deem necessary for the efficient discharge of its functions
under the provisions of this Act, on such terms and conditions of appointment and service
as may be prescribed.
25. The Chairperson, Members, officers and employees of the Board shall be deemed,
when acting or purporting to act in pursuance of provisions of this Act, to be public
servants within the meaning of section 21 of the Indian Penal Code.

extracted_data.requirement_title: Chairperson's Powers and Responsibilities
extracted_data.article_text:
14 THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY [P ART II—
26. The Chairperson shall exercise the following powers, namely:—
(a) general superintendence and giving direction in respect of all administrative
matters of the Board;
(b) authorise any officer of the Board to scrutinise any intimation, complaint,
reference or correspondence addressed to the Board; and
(c) authorise performance of any of the functions of the Board and conduct any
of its proceedings, by an individual Member or groups of Members and to allocate
proceedings among them.
CHAPTER VI
P
OWERS, FUNCTIONS AND PROCEDURE TO BE FOLLOWED BY BOARD
27. (1) The Board shall exercise and perform the following powers and functions,
namely:—
(a) on receipt of an intimation of personal data breach under sub-section (6) of
section 8, to direct any urgent remedial or mitigation measures in the event of a
personal data breach, and to inquire into such personal data breach and impose
penalty as provided in this Act;
(b) on a complaint made by a Data Principal in respect of a personal data breach
or a breach in observance by a Data Fiduciary of its obligations in relation to her
personal data or the exercise of her rights under the provisions of this Act, or on a
reference made to it by the Central Government or a State Government, or in compliance
of the directions of any court, to inquire into such breach and impose penalty as
provided in this Act;
(c) on a complaint made by a Data Principal in respect of a breach in observance
by a Consent Manager of its obligations in relation to her personal data, to inquire
into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this Act;
(d) on receipt of an intimation of breach of any condition of registration of a
Consent Manager, to inquire into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this
Act; and
(e) on a reference made by the Central Government in respect of the breach in
observance of the provisions of sub-section  (2) of section 37 by an intermediary, to
inquire into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this Act.
(2) The Board may, for the effective discharge of its functions under the provisions of
this Act, after giving the person concerned an opportunity of being heard and after recording
reasons in writing, issue such directions as it may consider necessary to such person, who
shall be bound to comply with the same.
(3) The Board may, on a representation made to it by a person affected by a direction
issued under sub-section ( 1) or sub-section ( 2), or on a reference made by the Central
Government, modify, suspend, withdraw or cancel such direction and, while doing so,
impose such conditions as it may deem fit, subject to which the modification, suspension,
withdrawal or cancellation shall have effect.
28. (1) The Board shall function as an independent body and shall, as far as practicable,
function as a digital office, with the receipt of complaints and the allocation, hearing and
pronouncement of decisions in respect of the same being digital by design, and adopt such
techno-legal measures as may be prescribed.
(2) The Board may, on receipt of an intimation or complaint or reference or directions
as referred to in sub-section (1) of section 27, take action in accordance with the provisions
of this Act and the rules made thereunder.

(3) The Board shall determine whether there are sufficient grounds to proceed with an
inquiry.
(4) In case the Board determines that there are insufficient grounds, it may, for reasons
to be recorded in writing, close the proceedings.
(5) In case the Board determines that there are sufficient grounds to proceed with
inquiry, it may, for reasons to be recorded in writing, inquire into the affairs of any person for
ascertaining whether such person is complying with or has complied with the provisions of
this Act.
(6) The Board shall conduct such inquiry following the principles of natural justice
and shall record reasons for its actions during the course of such inquiry.
(7) For the purposes of discharging its functions under this Act, the Board shall have
the same powers as are vested in a civil court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, in
respect of matters relating to—
(a) summoning and enforcing the attendance of any person and examining her
on oath;
(b) receiving evidence of affidavit requiring the discovery and production of
documents;
(c) inspecting any data, book, document, register, books of account or any
other document; and
(d) such other matters as may be prescribed.
(8) The Board or its officers shall not prevent access to any premises or take into
custody any equipment or any item that may adversely affect the day-to-day functioning of
a person.
(9) The Board may require the services of any police officer or any officer of the
Central Government or a State Government to assist it for the purposes of this section and
it shall be the duty of every such officer to comply with such requisition.
(10) During the course of the inquiry, if the Board considers it necessary, it may for
reasons to be recorded in writing, issue interim orders after giving the person concerned an
opportunity of being heard.
(11) On completion of the inquiry and after giving the person concerned an opportunity
of being heard, the Board may for reasons to be recorded in writing, either close the
proceedings or proceed in accordance with section 33.
(12) At any stage after receipt of a complaint, if the Board is of the opinion that the
complaint is false or frivolous, it may issue a warning or impose costs on the complainant.

Regularly monitor and review complaint trends to identify potential issues with the complaint review process or the definition of false or frivolous complaints. This review should be used to make adjustments to the process as needed.

controls.control_title: Review and Update Gain or Loss Determination Criteria

controls.control_title: Communicate Gain or Loss Determination Process to Stakeholders

controls.control_title: Penalty Amounts to be Credited to Consolidated Fund
controls.control: All sums realised by way of penalties imposed by the Board shall be credited to the Consolidated Fund of India. This includes all types of penalties, such as fines, fees, and other monetary penalties. The Board shall ensure that these amounts are accurately recorded and credited to the Consolidated Fund on a timely basis.

controls.control_title: Regular Audits to Verify Penalty Crediting
controls.control: The Board shall conduct regular audits to verify that all sums realised by way of penalties are being credited to the Consolidated Fund of India. These audits shall be conducted at least quarterly and shall cover all types of penalties imposed by the Board.

The Board shall maintain accurate and complete documentation of the process for crediting sums realised by way of penalties to the Consolidated Fund of India. This documentation shall include records of all penalties imposed, the amounts credited, and the dates of crediting.

controls.control_title: Separate Bank Account for Penalty Crediting
controls.control: The Board shall maintain a separate bank account for crediting sums realised by way of penalties to the Consolidated Fund of India. This account shall be used exclusively for crediting penalty amounts and shall be subject to regular audits and reconciliations.

controls.control: Establish a policy that clearly defines good faith actions and ensures that all employees understand the implications of taking actions in good faith. The policy should be communicated to all employees and made available on the organization's intranet or website.

Provide regular training to employees on the concept of good faith and how to apply it in their daily work. The training should cover scenarios where employees may be required to take actions that could potentially lead to legal proceedings.

Maintain accurate and detailed documentation of all actions taken by employees in good faith. This documentation should include the reasoning behind the actions, the steps taken, and the outcomes. The documentation should be easily accessible to employees and management.

Establish a communication plan to ensure that employees are aware of the good faith policy and the actions taken by the organization. This plan should include regular updates to employees, management, and stakeholders on the organization's good faith actions.

controls.control_title: Good Faith Review and Approval Process
controls.control: Establish a review and approval process for all actions taken by employees in good faith. This process should ensure that all actions are reviewed and approved by a designated authority before being implemented.

Provide regular training to staff on the procedures for collecting and reporting information to the Central Government. This will ensure that staff are aware of their responsibilities and can respond accurately and efficiently to information requests.

controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall provide clear and concise notice to the Data Principal regarding the collection, use, and disclosure of their personal data. This notice shall be easily accessible and understandable by the Data Principal.

The Data Fiduciary shall provide notice to the Data Principal in a timely manner, prior to collecting, using, or disclosing their personal data. This includes providing notice at the point of collection, if possible.

The Data Fiduciary shall maintain records of all notices provided to Data Principals, including the date and time of notice, the method of notice, and the content of the notice. These records shall be retained for a minimum of [insert time period].

The Data Fiduciary shall obtain explicit consent from the Data Principal prior to collecting, using, or disclosing their personal data, unless an exception applies under applicable law. The consent mechanism shall be transparent, informed, and freely given.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Reviews of Subsidy, Benefit, Service, Certificate, Licence or Permit Provision Rules

controls.control_title: Provide Training on Subsidy, Benefit, Service, Certificate, Licence or Permit Provision Rules

controls.control_title: Establish Accountability for Subsidy, Benefit, Service, Certificate, Licence or Permit Provision

controls.control_title: Monitor and Report on Subsidy, Benefit, Service, Certificate, Licence or Permit Provision
controls.control: Monitor and report on the provision or issuance of subsidies, benefits, services, certificates, licences, or permits, including any issues or concerns that arise. This monitoring and reporting should be conducted regularly and documented for future reference.

controls.control_title: Establish a Personal Data Breach Notification Policy
controls.control: Develop and implement a policy that outlines the form and manner of intimation of personal data breach to the Board. The policy should include procedures for identifying, assessing, and reporting personal data breaches.

controls.control_title: Designate a Personal Data Breach Notification Officer
controls.control: Appoint a designated officer responsible for receiving and processing notifications of personal data breaches. This officer should be aware of the procedures outlined in the notification policy and be able to escalate the matter to the Board as necessary.

controls.control_title: Develop a Personal Data Breach Notification Template
controls.control: Create a standardized template for notifying the Board of personal data breaches. The template should include essential information such as the nature of the breach, the affected data, and the proposed mitigation measures.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Training and Awareness Programs
controls.control: Provide regular training and awareness programs for employees on the procedures for reporting and responding to personal data breaches. This will ensure that employees are aware of their roles and responsibilities in the event of a breach.

controls.control_title: Establish a Personal Data Breach Incident Response Plan
controls.control: Develop a comprehensive incident response plan that outlines the procedures for responding to personal data breaches. The plan should include steps for containment, assessment, notification, and mitigation of the breach.

controls.control_title: Define Time Period for Purpose Deactivation
controls.control: Establish a clear and well-documented process for determining the time period for which data is deemed no longer being served for a specified purpose. This process should be reviewed and updated regularly to ensure it remains effective and compliant.

Develop and implement an automated process for deactivating data when the specified time period has expired. This process should be integrated with existing data management systems to ensure seamless operation.

Maintain a record of all decisions to deactivate data, including the reason for deactivation, the date of deactivation, and the individual responsible for making the decision. This documentation will help ensure transparency and accountability in the deactivation process.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Reviews of Deactivation Processes
controls.control: Schedule regular reviews of the deactivation process to ensure it remains effective and compliant. These reviews should be conducted by a designated team or individual and should include an assessment of the process's effectiveness, identification of areas for improvement, and implementation of any necessary changes.

Provide regular training to employees on the deactivation process, including the procedures for determining the time period for which data is deemed no longer being served and the process for deactivating data. This training will help ensure that employees understand their roles and responsibilities in the deactivation process.

controls.control_title: Publish Business Contact Information of Data Protection Officer on Public Website
controls.control: The business contact information of the Data Protection Officer shall be published on the organization's public website, including name, title, email address, and phone number. This information shall be easily accessible and clearly visible on the website's homepage or in a prominent location.

controls.control_title: Provide Alternative Contact Method for Data Protection Officer
controls.control: In addition to publishing the Data Protection Officer's contact information on the public website, an alternative contact method shall be provided, such as a dedicated email address or a contact form, to facilitate communication with the Data Protection Officer.

controls.control_title: Update Business Contact Information of Data Protection Officer Regularly
controls.control: The business contact information of the Data Protection Officer shall be reviewed and updated regularly, at least annually, to ensure that it remains accurate and up-to-date.

controls.control_title: Make Business Contact Information of Data Protection Officer Available in Multiple Languages
controls.control: The business contact information of the Data Protection Officer shall be made available in multiple languages, including the languages spoken by the organization's employees and the languages spoken by the organization's customers or clients.

controls.control_title: Provide Contact Information of Data Protection Officer in Privacy Policy
controls.control: The business contact information of the Data Protection Officer shall be included in the organization's privacy policy, which shall be easily accessible and clearly visible on the website.

controls.control: Ensure that consent language is clear, concise, and easily understandable by all stakeholders. This includes avoiding complex legal jargon and ensuring that the language is accessible to individuals with disabilities.

Provide individuals with all necessary information to make an informed decision about providing consent. This includes information about the purpose of data collection, the types of data being collected, and the potential risks and benefits associated with data collection.

Implement mechanisms to obtain verifiable consent, such as checkboxes, radio buttons, or explicit opt-in/opt-out options. Ensure that these mechanisms are easily accessible and usable by all stakeholders.
Maintain a record of all consent obtained, including the date, time, and method of consent. This will help to demonstrate compliance with consent requirements and provide a clear audit trail.

Establish a process for determining when consent expires, such as when an individual's data is no longer needed or when a new version of the consent is required. This will help to ensure that consent is up-to-date and relevant.

Establish a process for individuals to withdraw their consent at any time. This includes providing clear instructions on how to withdraw consent and ensuring that data is deleted or anonymized in a timely manner.

controls.control: Establish clear and distinct classes of Data Fiduciaries, including but not limited to, data controllers, data processors, and data protection officers, to ensure transparency and accountability in the processing of personal data of a child.

controls.control_title: Specify Purposes of Processing Personal Data of a Child
controls.control: Clearly define and document the purposes for which personal data of a child will be processed, including the collection, storage, and sharing of such data, to ensure that the processing is lawful and necessary for the specified purposes.

controls.control_title: Obtain Parental Consent for Processing Personal Data of a Child
controls.control: Implement procedures to obtain verifiable parental consent before processing personal data of a child, including providing clear and concise information about the purposes of processing, the types of data to be collected, and the rights of the child and their parents.

Implement an opt-out mechanism that allows children to refuse the processing of their personal data, including the collection, storage, and sharing of such data, and provide clear instructions on how to exercise this right.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of all data processing activities related to the personal data of a child, including the purposes of processing, the types of data collected, and the recipients of such data.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Data Protection Impact Assessments
controls.control: Conduct regular data protection impact assessments to identify and mitigate potential risks to the personal data of a child, including the risks of unauthorized access, disclosure, or loss of such data.

controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall establish a comprehensive data governance framework that outlines the policies, procedures, and standards for managing and protecting sensitive data. This framework shall be reviewed and updated regularly to ensure it remains effective and compliant with relevant regulations.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall conduct regular risk assessments to identify potential vulnerabilities and threats to sensitive data. These assessments shall be conducted at least annually and after any significant changes to the data environment.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall implement access controls to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to sensitive data. This shall include multi-factor authentication, role-based access controls, and regular reviews of user access privileges.

controls.control_title: Develop a Data Incident Response Plan
controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall develop a data incident response plan that outlines the procedures for responding to data breaches or other security incidents. This plan shall be reviewed and updated regularly to ensure it remains effective.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall provide regular data protection training to all personnel who handle sensitive data. This training shall cover best practices for data protection, including how to identify and report potential security incidents.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall conduct regular data audits to ensure that sensitive data is being stored and processed in accordance with the data governance framework. These audits shall be conducted at least annually and after any significant changes to the data environment.

controls.control: Implement a clear and conspicuous request mechanism that allows Data Principals to easily submit requests to the Data Fiduciary for information related to their personal data and its processing. This mechanism should be easily accessible and understandable by all Data Principals.

Develop a standardized request form that Data Principals can use to submit their requests. The form should include clear instructions and fields for the Data Principal to provide necessary information, such as their name, contact details, and specific requests for information.

Implement a request tracking and response mechanism that allows the Data Fiduciary to efficiently manage and respond to requests from Data Principals. This mechanism should include a system for tracking requests, assigning response deadlines, and sending notifications to Data Principals when their requests are processed.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date contact information for Data Principals, including their email addresses, phone numbers, and physical addresses. This information should be easily accessible by the Data Fiduciary to facilitate communication and response to requests.

Ensure that the request form is accessible to all Data Principals, including those with disabilities. This can be achieved by using accessible design principles, such as clear and simple language, high contrast colors, and compatibility with assistive technologies.

Provide the request form in multiple languages to accommodate Data Principals who may not be fluent in the primary language used by the Data Fiduciary. This can be achieved by using translation services or multilingual support tools.

controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall provide a clear and conspicuous mechanism for Data Principals to submit requests for erasure of their personal data. This mechanism shall be easily accessible and understandable by Data Principals, and shall include a clear description of the information required to process the request.

The Data Fiduciary shall provide a standard request form or template that Data Principals can use to submit their erasure requests. The form or template shall include fields for the Data Principal's contact information, a description of the personal data to be erased, and any other relevant information required to process the request.

The Data Fiduciary shall respond to erasure requests in a timely manner, and shall provide a clear explanation of the actions taken to process the request. If the request cannot be fulfilled, the Data Fiduciary shall provide a clear explanation of the reasons for the denial and any available alternatives.

The Data Fiduciary shall maintain a record of all erasure requests, including the date and time of receipt, the Data Principal's contact information, and the actions taken to process the request. This record shall be retained for a minimum of [insert timeframe] and shall be made available to Data Principals upon request.

The Data Fiduciary shall verify the identity of the Data Principal submitting the erasure request to ensure that the request is legitimate and not made by an unauthorized party. This verification shall be performed using a secure and reliable method, such as multi-factor authentication or knowledge-based authentication.

The Data Fiduciary shall provide confirmation to the Data Principal that their personal data has been erased, and shall provide a clear explanation of the actions taken to process the request. This confirmation shall be provided in a timely manner and shall be made available to the Data Principal in a format that is easily accessible and understandable.

controls.control_title: Establish a Rule and Notification Review Committee
controls.control: Establish a committee responsible for reviewing and approving rules and notifications before they are laid before each House of Parliament. The committee should comprise representatives from relevant departments, parliamentary officials, and external experts. The committee's review process should ensure that rules and notifications are compliant with the requirement and are properly documented.

controls.control_title: Develop a Rule and Notification Approval Process
controls.control: Develop a clear and transparent approval process for rules and notifications. The process should include clear roles and responsibilities, timelines, and decision-making criteria. The process should also ensure that all stakeholders are informed and consulted throughout the approval process.

controls.control_title: Implement a Rule and Notification Tracking System
controls.control: Implement a tracking system to monitor the progress of rules and notifications from submission to approval and laying before each House of Parliament. The system should provide real-time updates, reminders, and notifications to relevant stakeholders to ensure timely completion of the process.

controls.control_title: Provide Training and Awareness to Relevant Staff
controls.control: Provide regular training and awareness sessions to relevant staff on the rules and notification approval process, including their roles and responsibilities, timelines, and decision-making criteria. This will ensure that staff are equipped to support the process and make informed decisions.

controls.control_title: Establish a Compliance Monitoring and Reporting Framework
controls.control: Establish a framework to monitor and report on compliance with the requirement. The framework should include regular audits, reviews, and assessments to ensure that rules and notifications are being laid before each House of Parliament within the required timeframe. The framework should also provide recommendations for improvement and corrective actions.

controls.control: Conduct regular risk assessments for all third-party vendors and contractors to identify potential risks and vulnerabilities. This includes assessing the vendor's security controls, data handling practices, and compliance with relevant laws and regulations.

controls.control_title: Establish Clear Contracts with Third-Party Vendors
controls.control: Establish clear contracts with third-party vendors that include provisions for data security, confidentiality, and liability. Ensure that all contracts include provisions for regular security audits and compliance with relevant laws and regulations.

controls.control_title: Provide Security Awareness Training to Third-Party Vendors
controls.control: Provide security awareness training to all third-party vendors and contractors to educate them on the organization's security policies and procedures. This includes training on data handling practices, password management, and phishing attacks.

controls.control_title: Implement Incident Response Plan for Third-Party Breaches
controls.control: Implement an incident response plan to respond to third-party breaches. This includes procedures for identifying and containing breaches, notifying affected parties, and conducting post-incident reviews to identify lessons learned and areas for improvement.

extracted_data.requirement: Data Fiduciary shall take reasonable security safeguards to prevent personal data breach.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations must implement reasonable security measures to prevent data breaches.

controls.control: Implement access controls to restrict access to personal data to authorized personnel only. This includes multi-factor authentication, role-based access control, and least privilege access.
Encrypt all personal data both in transit and at rest to prevent unauthorized access. This includes using secure protocols for data transmission and encryption algorithms for data storage.
Regularly update and patch all systems, applications, and software to prevent exploitation of known vulnerabilities that could lead to a personal data breach.
Conduct regular security audits and risk assessments to identify potential vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the security controls and implement corrective actions to address them.
Implement an incident response plan to quickly respond to and contain a personal data breach in the event it occurs. This includes procedures for notification, containment, and remediation.
Train all personnel on security best practices and procedures to prevent personal data breaches. This includes training on data handling, access controls, and incident response.

extracted_data.requirement: Organizations shall comply with additional obligations in relation to children.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations must adhere to specific requirements when handling children's personal data.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Risk Assessments for Children
controls.control: Organizations shall conduct regular risk assessments to identify and mitigate potential risks to children, including physical, emotional, and psychological harm. This shall include assessing the organization's policies, procedures, and practices to ensure they are adequate to protect children.

controls.control_title: Implement Age Verification and Consent Mechanisms
controls.control: Organizations shall implement age verification and consent mechanisms to ensure that children are not accessing content or services that are not suitable for their age. This shall include obtaining parental consent for children under the age of 18 to access certain services or content.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Child Protection and Safeguarding
controls.control: Organizations shall provide regular training to staff on child protection and safeguarding, including recognizing signs of abuse and neglect, and reporting procedures. This shall ensure that staff are equipped to identify and respond to potential child protection issues.

Organizations shall establish a child protection policy that outlines their approach to protecting children, including procedures for reporting and responding to child protection concerns. This policy shall be communicated to all staff and stakeholders.

controls.control_title: Monitor Online Activities for Child Safety
controls.control: Organizations shall monitor online activities to ensure that children are not accessing content or services that are not suitable for their age. This shall include using filtering software and monitoring online interactions to prevent online grooming and exploitation.

controls.control_title: Provide Resources for Children and Families
controls.control: Organizations shall provide resources and support for children and families, including counseling services, educational materials, and access to child protection services. This shall ensure that children and families have access to the support they need to stay safe and healthy.

extracted_data.requirement: Significant Data Fiduciaries shall comply with additional obligations.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations that are significant data fiduciaries must adhere to specific requirements.

controls.control: Establish a comprehensive data governance framework that outlines data management policies, procedures, and standards for Significant Data Fiduciaries. This framework should include data classification, retention, and disposal policies, as well as procedures for data access, modification, and deletion.

Conduct regular data audits to ensure compliance with data governance policies and procedures. These audits should be conducted at least annually and should include reviews of data storage, processing, and transmission practices.

Implement data access controls that restrict access to sensitive data to authorized personnel only. This includes implementing role-based access controls, multi-factor authentication, and encryption for data in transit and at rest.
Develop a data breach response plan that outlines procedures for responding to data breaches, including notification requirements, incident response, and post-breach activities.

Provide regular data protection training to employees and contractors who handle sensitive data. This training should cover data handling best practices, data protection policies, and procedures for reporting data breaches.

Maintain a comprehensive data inventory that includes information about the types of data collected, stored, and transmitted by Significant Data Fiduciaries. This inventory should be updated regularly to reflect changes in data handling practices.

extracted_data.requirement: Organizations shall comply with duties under section 15.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations must fulfill specific duties as outlined in section 15.

controls.control: Establish a comprehensive compliance program that includes policies, procedures, and training to ensure adherence to section 15 requirements. The program should be regularly reviewed and updated to reflect changes in laws and regulations.

Appoint a dedicated compliance officer responsible for overseeing the organization's compliance with section 15. The compliance officer should have the necessary authority and resources to investigate and address any compliance issues.

Provide regular training and awareness programs for employees to educate them on section 15 requirements and their roles in ensuring compliance. The training should be tailored to the organization's specific needs and updated as necessary.

Conduct regular risk assessments to identify potential compliance risks associated with section 15. The risk assessment should be used to develop and implement mitigation strategies to address identified risks.

Develop and maintain policies and procedures that are specific to section 15 requirements. The policies and procedures should be easily accessible to employees and regularly reviewed and updated as necessary.

Establish a system for reporting and tracking compliance with section 15 requirements. The system should include regular reporting to management and the compliance officer to ensure ongoing compliance.

extracted_data.requirement: Organizations shall comply with voluntary undertakings accepted by the Board.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations must adhere to terms agreed upon in voluntary undertakings with the Board.

controls.control_title: Establish a Board-approved Voluntary Undertakings Policy
controls.control: Develop and maintain a policy that outlines the organization's approach to voluntary undertakings, including the process for accepting and implementing undertakings, and ensure that the policy is approved by the Board.

controls.control_title: Designate a Responsible Officer for Voluntary Undertakings
controls.control: Appoint a senior officer who is responsible for overseeing the organization's voluntary undertakings, including ensuring that undertakings are implemented in accordance with the organization's policies and procedures.
Maintain a record of all voluntary undertakings accepted by the organization, including the terms and conditions of each undertaking, and ensure that the records are up-to-date and easily accessible.

controls.control_title: Communicate Voluntary Undertakings to Relevant Parties
controls.control: Ensure that all relevant parties, including employees, contractors, and stakeholders, are aware of the organization's voluntary undertakings and their responsibilities in relation to those undertakings.

Regularly review and update the organization's voluntary undertakings to ensure that they remain relevant and effective, and that they continue to align with the organization's policies and procedures.

extracted_data.requirement: Organizations shall comply with all provisions of the Act and its rules.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations must adhere to all requirements outlined in the Act and its rules.

controls.control: Develop and implement a comprehensive compliance program that includes policies, procedures, and training to ensure all employees understand the Act and its rules. The program should be regularly reviewed and updated to ensure ongoing compliance.

Appoint a qualified individual as the Compliance Officer who will be responsible for overseeing the compliance program, investigating compliance issues, and reporting to senior management and the board of directors.

Provide regular training and awareness programs for all employees to ensure they understand the Act and its rules, as well as their roles and responsibilities in maintaining compliance. Training should be documented and updated regularly.

Establish a system to monitor and report compliance with the Act and its rules. This includes tracking compliance metrics, identifying areas for improvement, and reporting compliance issues to senior management and the board of directors.

Maintain accurate and complete records of compliance-related activities, including training, monitoring, and reporting. Records should be easily accessible and retained for a minimum of [insert timeframe].

Develop and implement a whistleblower policy that allows employees to report compliance concerns anonymously. The policy should include procedures for investigating and addressing reported concerns, as well as protecting employees from retaliation.
